item.title: Blog Post 3: Polling
item.description: Overview Last week, I developed a comprehensive structure that can be used to build a model that combines the fundamentals with a current snapshot of the political climate in order to forecast the electoral college. The model proceeded in three steps: Forecast each state’s elasticity, which represents the change in state-level vote margin between two election cycles. This metric measures the “swinginess” of a state. Forecast each state’s partisan lean, which measures the extent to which a state is either more democratic or more republican than the national popular vote.

item.title: Blog Post 2: Economic Fundamentals
item.description: Overview This week, I will expand the predictive model for the 2024 presidential election that I developed last week. In my previous model, I used the “partisan lean index” (PLI) — which measures the difference between the state’s democratic two-party vote share and the two party democratic vote share nationwide, and includes adjustments for home state advantage and state-level population density — in the previous two election cycles to predict the electoral college results for the current election cycle.

item.title: Blog Post 1: Historical Election Data
item.description: In this first blog post, I will analyze and visualize historical presidential election data in order to better understand trends in the electoral college and develop a naive predictive model for the 2024 election.
